356. Sargent, (Mrs. Charles Evans)
What did early Canadian housewives eat?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Smith Elizabeth Redmond Sargent.

Address: 207-30th St., Saskatoon, Sask.

Birthplace: India.

1. DEMOGRAPHIC QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1918 April

Where did you set up housekeeping? 207-30th St., Sask.

Where had you been living before that? 1914-1918, England

As nurse on 16 crossings Atlantic

For how many people did you prepare meals? Three

How far was it to your nearest store? 15 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea; coffee; salt; sugar; flour; oatmeal; canned fruits; canned tomatoes; mostly pineapple.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household, also, eye flour, & potato flour.

In what quantities did you buy it? Hundred pound bags, after war restrictions lifted, 100 lb. con tins.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.00

How much did you use Graham flour? 25%

Whole wheat flour? 25%

Was flour milled locally? No, far away? 45 mi. That year? 1914-1940

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Corn starch

What other grain products did you use? Corn meal

Cornmeal? Yes, occasionally whole wheat? Yes, Farina? Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes

How did you grind it? Roller mill used for whole meal bread. Ground wheat was sifted, the finer portion mixed with white flour for bread and the coarser cooked for breakfast food.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ........................................ House cured pork & bacon.
How did you get fresh meat? .............................................................. Traded pork for beef with neighbour by the quarter in winter. Occasionally from store in summer.
How often did you get fresh meat? ........................................................ Not more than once a month in summer.
How did you preserve meat? .............................................................. Salted and kept in wet brine.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ........................................ Yes.
If so what year was it organized? ........................................................ 1820.
Did you use game? .............................................................. What kinds? Hungarian partridge; Wild duck, geese & occasional turkey. Very occasionally Jack-rabbit.
For how long? .................................................................................... Possibly three months in fall & winter.
What part did fish play in the family diet? ................................................ Occasional treat.
Canned fish little often.
Has the fish fresh, cured, or canned? .................................................... All kinds.
Kinds? Fresh, haddock, trout, bass, very occasionally salmon. Cured, hippers, canned, salmon, sardines.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ................................................................. Well

How far was this water from your home? .................................................. 300 ft.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................................... Pails

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible. New wella dug 1924 and 1934 close to old ones.

1918. Soft water cistern. Galvanized iron. 10 gal.

1920. Fixed folding bath tub, with cistern oil heated, and drainpipe to garden.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal.

Where did you get your fuel? Lethbridge & Co.

What was the main source of heating? Fireplaces.

Describe any changes in the use of fuels since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

1928. High test gas four burner stove with oven.

1948. Oil burning heater.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the reason and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Oatmeal porridge; Eggs & Bacon; Jam; Coffee.
Dinner: Hot meat; rice pudding; apple pie; Cheese; Tea.
Supper: Cold ham; fruit (home canned); cookies; cake; Tea.

All meals: Homemade bread—white and brown.

18. May... Three people. Ages 39--28--17.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

But in 1914--1915 my husband had to get through the winter on $12 after buying his coal, and lived almost entirely on oatmeal porridge, completing his homestead duties with 35¢ to spare at the end of April.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No

But in 1914--1915 my husband had to get through the winter on $12 after buying his coal, and lived almost entirely on oatmeal porridge, completing his homestead duties with $5 to spare at the end of April.
20. Notice any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

We now use much more fresh fruit and fruit juices; much less meat; more soups; fewer milk puddings; more steamed or canned fruit. More varied breakfast foods replacing oatmeal in summer. Meals now are generally not nearly so heavy as in the early days, probably due to machinery having replaced heavy manual work.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homecanned and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Can't say we do. Still rely on homestead and home prepared foods, but do use more purchased foods by way of change & variety as treats.

Or should I say, Nov 5-1950, when for the first time since starting housekeeping on the Homestead, we moved into the city for the winter months.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
